title: Why did Singapore ban gum?
intro: Do you chew gum and what do you do with it when you've finished? Listen to Rob and Finn discussing the history and chemical properties of gum and why it's messing up our streets whilst explaining some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: When did the Singapore government outlaw chewing gum?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: not caring about other people and society in general
a sticky substance produced by trees
friendly and easy to talk to
a situation where onething is joined firmly with another.
involves a lot of people to do something
breaks down into smaller pieces over time
small round ball of something that has become hard

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob...

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: ...and I'm Finn. Hello.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello, Finn! Are you chewing gum over there?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Yeah. Oh hang on – I'll just stick it under the desk for now.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yuck – that's revolting! Why don't you go and put it in the bin? Since when did you take up this antisocial habit? Antisocial means annoying to other people, by the way.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Yeah, well. OK, Rob. Fine. Since I heard that there was evidence that chewing gum can improve your brain.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So how does it do that?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Well, some experts say that the chewing action can lead to an increase in blood flow to the brain.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Interesting! And guess what, we're taking about chewing gum on today's programme! So here's a question for you, Finn. When did the Singapore government outlaw chewing gum? Was it in...

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: And just before I answer, to outlaw something means to make it illegal. Well, I think the answer is a) 1982.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, we'll chew on it for a while, shall we, and find out if you're right at the end of the programme.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: So, Rob, what's the history of chewing gum?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, people have been chewing gum for thousands of years. The Ancient Greeks chewed gum made from resin – a sticky substance produced by trees. But why do people like chewing gum?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Well, for many people it's just something to do. But you know, I like the idea that it's good for my brain. Research has shown that people find gum chewers are also more approachable – that means they're friendlier and easier to talk to.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. Well, there might be some truth in that. The thing we're here to discuss today, though, is how to dispose – or get rid – of gum responsibly. And you didn't set a very good example earlier in the show, did you, Finn?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Ah, well. Yeah, no, I didn't. But lots of people dispose of gum irresponsibly – that means not responsibly. It's often found stuck underneath tables, chairs, benches and escalators. And it's really difficult and expensive to remove once it has dried.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right – because gum actually creates a chemical bond – which means when one thing joins firmly to another. For example it bonds with tarmac roads, rubber shoe soles, and concrete paving.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: So how do we remove dried gum from roads and pavements? Rob, how would you do it?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, people do use high-pressure steam cleaners and then they scrape it off. But it's a slow process that's labour-intensive – which means it takes a lot of people to do it.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: I'm sure it does. So let's hear someone telling a BBC reporter about why they threw their gum away in the street. Can you hear the reason she gives?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Woman: Not that often. I often put it in the bin. Reporter: But you do it sometimes? Woman: Yeah, sometimes. Reporter: Why do you do it sometimes? Woman: I don't know. Because there's no bins around.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Now, she says she throws her gum in the street when she can't find a bin.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So, why doesn't she put it in her pocket and wait until she finds a bin?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Ah, no. No way, man! That's – that would make her pocket sticky!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh dear – it sounds like you and her are two of a kind – and that means very similar. OK, well, let's find out what another gum chewer does.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Reporter: If you're walking along the street, and you had some other, a packet of crisps, when you'd finished it, would you throw that away? Man: Not really. Reporter: So why do you sometimes throw the chewing gum away? What's the difference? Man: It's like food. It's not like a wrapper. Do you know what I mean?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: So, this guy says gum is like food, so it's OK to drop it on the ground. Do you agree, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: No, I don't. Food, such as a discarded apple core or banana skin, quickly and naturally degrades – or breaks down. And other types of litter, for example, a crisp packet or a sweet wrapper, can be picked up easily.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: That's right. Whereas chewing gum is a bit like glue once it dries and it's extremely difficult to remove. So, in this way, of course, it can also be environmentally damaging.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: In 2000 a study of a busy London shopping street showed that a quarter of a million pellets of chewing gum were stuck to the pavement. And a pellet is a small round ball of something that has become hard.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: That's a lot of pellets, isn't it! The amount of discarded gum in Singapore was considered to be such a problem that the government banned the sale and consumption of gum altogether. They said it was because people were sticking their gum in the sliding doors of subway trains, stopping the doors from opening and closing.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, it's a sticky subject isn't it?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: It is indeed. A sticky situation, Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And that brings us on to today's quiz question! I asked you earlier: when did the Singapore government outlaw chewing gum? Was it in… a) 1982? b) 1992? or c) 2002?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: I said a) 1982.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: You are wrong, Finn, just for today. The answer is actually b) 1992.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Which means the people of Singapore could chew gum for ten more years than I said. That's good. Now, how about those words again, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, well, the words we heard today were:

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Well, that brings us to the end of today's 6 Minute English. We hope you've had plenty to chew on in today's programme. And you can hear more programmes at bbclearningenglish.com . Join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
